entry.title: Combined summary - Cartographer
entry.summary: The context provided discusses various topics related to Bitcoin and its infrastructure. It highlights the limitations of using DNS as a protocol for learning about the p2p network, including difficulties in providing extra data in responses beyond IP address and signing responses being awkward with DNS. The author argues that using a simple HTTP-based protocol fixes all these problems at once and recommends Cartographer as a better protocol overall. On December 29, 2014, Mike Hearn was accused of attempting to introduce privacy leaks and weaknesses in the Bitcoin ecosystem, as well as using logical fallacies such as ad hominem attacks, disruption, and FUD. The sender questions why Hearn responds to objections with hand waving and misdirection instead of sound technical reasoning.Another message from the same day shows a conversation between Thomas Zander and Mike Hearn discussing the limitations of the current DNS protocol. Mike made an ad-hominem attack by calling someone "a parody," which Thomas and a third party deemed unacceptable behavior in any collaborative group. However, Thomas focused on criticizing the idea itself rather than engaging in personal attacks.Moreover, the context mentions malware infecting DNS seeds, leading to aggressive networks blocking them. Gregory Maxwell's suggestion of permuting the results with XOR can easily fix this issue. However, the end-user driven solution misses out on the needs of other Bitcoin stakeholders like law enforcement and marketing companies.The context also discusses a new network crawler and seed that implements a standard DNS seed with a minimal embedded DNS server. This seed can serve seed data using gzipped, timestamped digitally signed protocol buffers over HTTP, which fixes authentication, auditability, malware false positives, and extensibility. In addition, it can also serve data in JSON, XML, and HTML for ease of use with other tools.In conclusion, the given context covers various topics related to Bitcoin infrastructure, including limitations of the DNS protocol, solutions to malware infection, and arguments about privacy and the use of protocols. However, there were disagreements and personal attacks during discussions on this topic. Further discussion and collaboration are needed to address these concerns and find alternative solutions.
